message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest acute angle closure glaucoma, and the most appropriate next step in management is to perform gonioscopy to confirm the diagnosis. Ultrasound biomicroscopy is useful in assessing the anterior segment of the eye but is not necessary at this point. Fundoscopy is not indicated due to the symptoms and the emergency nature of the situation. Administering topical steroids is not appropriate as it may worsen the condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma. Gonioscopy is a diagnostic tool for glaucoma that can assess the angle structures of the eye. Ultrasound biomicroscopy and fundoscopy are not helpful in diagnosing glaucoma. Administering topical steroids may worsen the condition. Intravenous analgesia and antiemetics are appropriate for symptom relief.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest acute angle-closure glaucoma, which requires prompt treatment to prevent permanent vision loss. Gonioscopy is used to assess the angle between the iris and cornea and determine the extent of angle closure. Ultrasound biomicroscopy can also be helpful in diagnosing and managing this condition. Fundoscopy and topical steroids are not appropriate next steps in management for acute angle-closure glaucoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including severe pain around the right eye, blurred vision, headache, and colored bright circles when looking at a light source, suggest acute angle-closure glaucoma, which can cause permanent vision loss if not treated promptly. Gonioscopy is used to determine the degree of angle closure and the appropriate treatment plan. Perform ultrasound biomicroscopy and fundoscopy are not appropriate at this time, and administering topical steroids is contraindicated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest acute angle-closure glaucoma. Gonioscopy can confirm the diagnosis and is the most appropriate next step. Fundoscopy and ultrasound biomicroscopy may be needed later but are not the first diagnostic procedures to be performed. Administering topical steroids may worsen the condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including severe eye pain, blurred vision, and dilated and fixed pupil, suggest acute angle-closure glaucoma, which requires gonioscopy to examine and confirm the diagnosis. Performing fundoscopy is also important to check for any damage caused by the increased intraocular pressure. Administering topical steroids without first confirming the diagnosis can worsen the condition. Ultrasound biomicroscopy can be helpful, but not the most appropriate next step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the patient suggest acute angle-closure glaucoma, which is a medical emergency. Gonioscopy should be performed to assess the angle between the cornea and the iris and determine whether there is angle closure. Performing ultrasound biomicroscopy or administering topical steroids are not appropriate initial management steps. Fundoscopy may be necessary later in management but is not the most appropriate next step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest acute angle-closure glaucoma, and the most appropriate next step in management is to perform gonioscopy, which examines the drainage angle of the eye to confirm the diagnosis. Ultrasound biomicroscopy and fundoscopy can be done later to assess for any damage caused by the increased pressure. Administering topical steroids would be contraindicated in this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest acute angle-closure glaucoma, and the most appropriate next step in management is to perform gonioscopy to evaluate the anterior chamber angle and determine whether it is open or closed. Ultrasound biomicroscopy is a diagnostic test that can provide detailed images of the anterior segment of the eye, but it is not indicated as the first step in management. Fundoscopy may be indicated later to evaluate the retina, but it is not the most appropriate next step. Administering topical steroids is not indicated at this point and may worsen the condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and exam findings suggest acute angle-closure glaucoma, which requires urgent management to prevent further vision loss. Performing gonioscopy can confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment with laser iridotomy. Ultrasound biomicroscopy would not be necessary for diagnosis or management. Fundoscopy may not be possible due to corneal edema and pain. Administering topical steroids may worsen the condition.
